issue.title: Stopwatch.StartStopReset test is flaky on windows

content.raw: Just so I'm understanding the `2000040 us vs 2000000 us` error: The test is suppose to check that the first value is greater than or equal to the second, and the test fails with output that contradicts the test failure. Is that correct?
content.html: Just so I'm understanding the 2000040 us vs 2000000 us error: The test is suppose to check that the first value is greater than or equal to the second, and the test fails with output that contradicts the test failure. Is that correct?

issue.title: Stopwatch.StartStopReset test is flaky on windows

content.html: hm. I'm calling the function again during the debug print, so it might not be the same time anymore. let me try again with 8d9d238

issue.title: Stopwatch.StartStopReset test is flaky on windows

content.raw:
Yeah, I think we can ignore those weird measurements that appeared to satisfy the expectation because it was reading the timer twice and getting different values. It makes more sense now

~~~

issue.title: Stopwatch.StartStopReset test is flaky on windows

content.raw: maybe the Stopwatch is traveling at relativistic speeds
content.html: maybe the Stopwatch is traveling at relativistic speeds

issue.title: Stopwatch.StartStopReset test is flaky on windows

content.raw: I believe windows implementation of `sleep_for` uses a `system_clock` instead of a `steady_clock`. See (here)[https://stackoverflow.com/questions/35741656/stdthis-threadsleep-for-sleeps-shorter-than-expected-in-vs2015]. I think I can alter the test to account for this.
content.html: I believe windows implementation of sleep_for uses a system_clock instead of a steady_clock. See (here)[https://stackoverflow.com/questions/35741656/stdthis-threadsleep-for-sleeps-shorter-than-expected-in-vs2015]. I think I can alter the test to account for this.
